												It's okay but wasn't as fun as I had hoped. It has some nice ideas but is too lengthy with too little variety and bored me throughout numerous parts. It lacks difficulty and challenge and playing it can feel like a tedious chore. I got used to the looks of each level quickly. You change between reality and Wonderland scenes in a predictable succession. They can appear initially impressive but everything submits heavily to the basic mechanics. There isn't much feeling of consistency or meaning, the levels are cluttered and lack elements to excite you with. One could end in a minute and the other in hours and it would still amount to the same. Sometimes while platforming you change without too much of a warning between various graphical dimensions and visual styles or even have the game turn into a sidescrolling shooter. Some of these sections fit the themes of the levels they happen in nicely and were interesting to witness but gameplay-wise turned repetitive soon. You hardly ever interact with anyone or anything that isn't a mob to slash at but move on and on traversing the always kinda same ways and exploring the kinda same secret passages to unlock collectibles you might care or not about. Having a deranged protagonist explore her mind to sort things out regarding her psyche, her real-life situation and that Wonderland of hers could've offered lots of possibilites to deal with your environments and their inhabitants, and the "interim" scenes of switching worlds were rather interesting but the game dares not to progress beyond it's otherwise predictable level patterns and fundamental platforming and combat mechanics which leaves the rather nice voice actors severly underused as well.There isn't much substance to the characters. They aren't very tangible, they don't have too many lines and when they speak they do it in ways or making references to previous events or characters that can be hard to understand (without being necessarily complicated by nature) for non-native English speakers or when not knowing the book this is based on or the previous game "American McGee’s Alice". There isn't too much of story progression. You're jumping and slashing your way through the mind of Alice, sometimes moving around the real life, facing a predictable twist, some end boss and a relatively vague open end. My ultimate feeling was, I believe, that I haven't accomplished much. There really isn't much I would've missed had I not played this. I dare not go as far as I regret my time with this game but I wasn't particularily enthusiastic about it either.What is nice is how monsters (visually; the combat never becomes too diverse or interesting) and Alice are designed. The latter has beautiful hair and clothes (in grim Gothic style) flutter around (I suggest manually unlocking the otherwise hidden dresses DLC content) and the game makes pretty heavy use of NVIDIA PhysX which leads to very realistic and impressive particles and puddles of black goo one main set of enemies leaves behind.  The game is by default locked to 30 FPS which I advise fixing via some .ini file as mentioned by other reviewers because it makes the game look better (some menus load more smoothly then as well). That aside, within the context of its gameplay/story/characer limits, the game works techncially nicely and is pretty foolproof. So if you can forgive its repetitiveness, have the patience to go through it and don't expect any great story or character display you can still have an experience of something.

												The whole game wound up being a love-hate experience for me: I love the game for its aesthetics, but the biggest problems I had dealt with the gameplay. The game took me about 19 hours to complete and I don't think the gameplay felt it was worth that amount of time. I have no desire to go through it again. However, if you want presentation and/or a hack-n-slash with cool "toys", then you might enjoy this game.The details…Pros: Beautifully grotesque surreal imagery and intriguing symbolism. Some of the cut scenes are presented as paper-cutouts (as homage to Through the Looking-Glass) these are interesting and are used at appropriate times. Story becomes more engaging as clues start falling into place. Finding secrets and trying to collect everything in each level is satisfying. The eerie soundtrack.Cons: Despite the game throwing many enemies at you, the difficulty curve seems nonexistent. (Played on normal.) Most of the enemy encounters will be the same (i.e. Insidious Ruin, the game's most basic enemy), which led the battles to become stale and repetitive. (I would have prefered a big mixture of multiple types of enemies--including more minibosses thrown in-- to improve this issue.) The game attempts to give the player a change of pace by giving mandatory mini-games, however these play like cheap mobile apps and are ultimately…pretty lame. They happen way more often then they should too. The "tips" are so obvious it's insulting to the player's intelligence. Too hand-holding and no punishment for failure:For example, when you die, whether it’s by health loss or falling, you respawn on the previous platform and continue fighting where you left off (i.e. enemies don't spawn from scratch when you die).  Level designs fall short due to being dull and repetitive, new features aren't added until near the end of the game, such as the balancing platforms.The game destroys the balance it initially created:The Vorpal Blade has fast combo strikes, but is used for only close combat. Makes Sense. The Pepper Grinder is long-ranged, but has to recharge. Alright. The Hobby Horse breaks enemy armor, but is slower and is close-combat. Fair Enough. The Teapot Cannon (acquired about halfway through the game) is long-ranged, breaks enemy armor, kills groups of enemies and will be ready from any cool-downs before the next shot. Well, that’s overpowered, if you ask me. The Teapot Cannon negates the use and upgrading of all other weapons, with the exception of the Clockwork Bomb (non-upgradable) which can be used to distract and lump together most enemies for easier targets.  Many glitches for PC, including, but not limited to: dropping frame rate, unable to move, camera stuck in L-targeting even after enemy death, enemies clipping into walls and disappearing, falling through platforms while standing still.

												Excellent and engaging combat set in imaginative and dazzling worlds, with a marvellous soundtrack. Marred mostly by tedious and repetitive level design, frustrating camera and enemy lock-in issues, and a bit rough around the edges with regards to bugs and smooth controls. The minigames are a bit crap, too.It's a dark, twisted little number with flowery writing and a fairly interesting, if predictable, story. The graphics aren't too bad but clearly aimed at consoles, but little features like Alice's hair and dress flowing as she moves adds a nice touch (I believe the game was a bit of a tech demo for Nvidia's hair rendering tech, but it looked nice enough on my AMD card).If there was more emphasis on combat than platforming (The latter is so easy you'll be hard pressed to ever be challenged by it), I'd have probably enjoyed it much more, especially with the potential of enemy combinations they could have had.Still, recommended, it's charming enough that boring and linear level design is at least eclipsed by good combat, writing, and art direction.

												5/10Not a very good game. While visually interesting at first, the polish and freshness runs out in the first half hour or so, and  the game turns into endless copy pasted envirnments. The screenshots above are not representative of the game as a whole, and that trailer is even worse. While I'm not one to gripe about graphics, the character models look and move like ps2 era npcs. The game also runs fairly poorly, with freezing and frame skipping on a regular basis, and whenever anything chaotic happens the game slows to a crawl. The enemy designs are not particularly varied, and the main type of enemy is repeated ad nosium, the only variants simply being bigger versions of the small ones. The plot is virtually none existant, and isn't communicated much to the player except through vague and incongruently drawn cutscenes. Perhaps those who played the original (or prequel? the relationship is unclear in this game) game American Mcgee's Alice would get more here, but as for this game on its own, practically no story. Voice acting gets irritating very quickly, especially the main npc's like hatter and march hare, and a lot of the clips sound like they don't even belong in the game (muted or too quiet, jumpy breaks between lines). The voice actress playing Alice sounds incredibly bored the whole time. Game play is straight forward and gets stale very quickly, and the few minigames end up being tedious. Platforming is not great, as alice's jumping mechanics are hard to control. A section around the middle in the souls locker area is particularly tedious thanks to the bad controls. Overall, a great first thirty minutes, but it overstays its welcome beyond that and becomes a generic, gray hack and slash. Might as well just play God of War or any other game with this exact formula. TLDR: In conclusion, gray and generic.  Best parts are the menus and the first two areas. Runs like crap with bad controls. Mind numbing and time cocnsuming as it goes on, even the characters are bored. In a word, Mediocre.

												I really wanted to like Alice: Madness Returns, and I do like some things about it. The story is a dark and deep tale of a young girl with a shattered mind. The characters, both real and imaginary, are compelling. The art dances back and forth between hauntingly beautiful and terrifyingly grotesque. Unfortunately, the game falters when it comes to combat and level design. The combat is exciting and visceral in the earlier levels but quickly becomes a hassle as the lock-on system allows off-screen enemies to repeatedly assault you with lunges and ranged attacks. Meanwhile, the level design is outdated, completely linear, and relies heavily on a small handful overused mechanics. Oddly, there is an interesting "shrinking" mechanic that seems to have a lot of potential, but never evolves beyond fitting into small holes and finding invisble platforms. These glaring flaws aside, there are also more than a few bugs - especially in later levels. If you can look past these issues there is a good game somewhere in there, but overall, Madness Returns just feels unpolished.

												Casual platformer with an amazing aesthetic (the art book and soundtrack for this game on Amazon is probably worth it alone). I stress casual becuase it isn't particular difficult. The type of platforming is rather nastalgic in a sort of early Crash Bandicoot 3d platformer sort of way.I downvoted this game because the PC port is regretably bad. The console suffered from texture pop ins, but on the PC you start to see screen tears, and dramatic frame droppage. It should be worth noting gameplay wise, if you can stomach the bugs... the first few levels are lackluster, the water levels in particular are incredible boring. I fully recomend grabbing some coffee in order for you to trudge on through this part. Story is weak and unfathomable at times during the first half of the game (water level being the prime offender), but after the water level the plot starts to be more understandable and at times, interesting. Although many of the Wonderland characters are vague to a fault. I can only imagine this is the case in order for the mystery in the story to remain a mystery (albiet the cut scenes sort of spoil it, won't elaborate how, but in the defense of the developers it was done by a different studio at the last moment).

content:
4, 2014
												Hands down the best game I've played all year and most definitely one of the best games I've played ever.American McGee has made an incredible comeback with this sequel. I fondly remember playing American McGee's Alice in high school but Madness Returns is volumes better in all aspects of concept, storyline, graphics, and gameplay. This game takes on more of a platform concept which incorporates plenty of jumping, twirling, and floating in the air. This is a beautiful psychological horror game with jaw dropping artwork and a very developed storyline. It is a highly grotesque game in all the right ways. Mcgee takes an even further step away from the classic Alice prototype and recreates an even more disturbing and grown up Wonderland. The fighting in this game is much more complex than the original and it is gorgeous to watch. The vorpal blade is the only returning weapon, but there are new and more exciting weapons including the hobby horse, which was probably my favourite addition. Alice's outfits change with her state of mind and the parts of Wonderland which she visits. There are "mini-game" sections added throughout that are fun to play. Absolutely brilliant game. Highly recommend. 10/10

content:
10, 2014
												Alice: Madness Returns is the sequel to the cult hit American McGee's Alice. This is a game that takes the familiar wonderland and turns it on its head, making it a morbid, gruesome and dangerous place. In this game, Wonderland is the delusion of a disturbed girl who is seeking an escape from her dreary life and forgiveness for her failures. Alice really delivers in terms of striking visuals and an art style that is reminiscent of the films of Tim Burton, but different enough that it doesn't feel like a direct imitation. Alice herself changes in each zone of the game, her dress taking on different elements of goth, S&M or Steampunk attire. Enemies and npcs are bizarre and magical and discovering more of them compels one to continue playing.  The only thing I dislike about Alice is how familiar it feels. It is very much an action platformer at its heart, with Alice taking on the monsters of Wonderland and of her own psyche with a magical butcher knife and a pepper grinder which acts as a machine gun. However, it is a very strong action platformer with plenty of hidden areas and challenging jumping puzzles that make the experience compelling, challenging and rewarding. While the game is in a genre that I feel stopped being intresting in the early 2000s, Alice has interesting enough scenery and characters and a good enough overall story to keep most players interested. It is worth it for the visuals alone. Play this one if you want to play a fun, challenging game that is not too deep.

er 26, 2014
												Absolutely love Alice: Madness Returns. This is a sequel game from American McGee's Alice where we are forward several years later into which Alice Liddel is forged into a orphanage run by Dr. Bumby (a powerful man who manipulates children's minds in to forgetting their own past by destroying their present which Alice slowly realizes on her own). The game takes place in the early/mid 1800's which gives the area of the game a dark Tim Burton affect as well as how the character's look with a slight cartoonish look to them. The game by far is absolutely beautiful with it's graphics and with the whole story all together. For a game that was made in 2011, its graphics were far above fabulous. What I like about this game is that it get's harder and more frustrating (rage-quit effective) but is hard to stop playing with the story tagged along with it's graphics. The only complaint that I don't like about the game is some lag in the movie cuts and in some parts of the game where some tutorials are being explained but that shouldnt stop you or anyone into having such a great time with this game. Another thing i would like to mention is that this game is rated "M" for a reason because of sexual inuendo's/influences, slight drugs, and tons of violence so if you are not comfortable with any of these i would not reccomend it since Alice: Madness Returns is a very dark and disturbing game to play and some people can't handle it while others like myself can handle it. For those of you who haven't heard of American McGee's Alice (which I didn't either after looking into this game) it is OKAY! The sequal explains everything that happened in the last game so you don't have to worry spending a couple bucks on buying it (it was made in 2000 so the graphics were a little choppy but still a good story). Now the last thing I would like to say is that there is a huge possibility of Alice: Otherlands becoming a third installment to the Alice Series but also the last since the series has been running for quite sometime. It will either be turned into a Mini-Series sold on DVD or BluRay or another video game (which I am happy for either production). So if you love the Alice Series i'm sure you will love what is coming soon. I rate this game a 9 1/2 out of 10. (9 1/2 because of some lag but other than that there is nothing to complain about!). Now do yourself a favour, get this game because you won't regret it!

												After Finally finishing his game, Here are my thoughts.This game is focused on a girl named alice which she is recovering from her family's death from a house fire which people around town say was a "accident" by a cat who knocked over a lamp, she belives someone else might have cause it, By going through her mind's "wonderland", meeting strange characters all messed up from the orignial fairy tail, collecting memories and shooting pig snouts with some pepper. You'll find the truth to who actually killed your family!Pros: Good visuals, good level designs and voices. actual good story. Dresses that not only make you look good, give out some abitities to make the game harder or easier. New game plus +, allowing you to carry your stuff over if you decide to play again.Combat is good as you have weapons for different enemies, who are fast or may have high defense.Collectables.Cons: the game has a frame cap set at "30" and you want to increase it by checking out the guide.Some dress and weapons are locked for some reason and you also need to read the guide to unlock them.The game rarely, but sometimes freezes for a good 2 seconds before resume. Camera shifts a bit funky but doable.(Ending was a bit strange, but you decide on that one!)Over all it was a fun and good game, it had those moments where you felt, alone, scared, One moment everything is all nice the sun is out, birds are chirping and boom it gets all scaryand dark!,(like the under the sea level, those poor fish...)  Also its not all just about combat, but exploring, jumping, platforming, finding hidden items and solving puzzles. If you didn't know a puzzle you could just skip it if your not the puzzle type. Also Razputin from psychonauts is there, go find him, he's been wanting to "pick a bone" with you. ;)I give it a 8.9/10, pick it up when it's on sale I recommend it. Have a good one lad!

												If you like Psychonauts, then you're likely to enjoy Alice: Madness Returns; (in fact, there's an easter egg that gives a nod to Psychonauts in the Queen's Castle). Like Psychonauts, it's a highly stylized action-adventure platformer with amazing characters, story, and level design. er 16, 2014
												This is one of the games I wish steam had a neutral rating for.Pros:Theme (Traveling through Alices shattered mind.)Atmosphere (Nice and creepy, and each area has it's on feel to it.)Visuals (Decent graphics with a unique style to them.)Animation (Combat animation seemed fluid to me. Her hair sure has more animation that I expected.)Costumes (Different one for every chapter it seems, one makes her look like Wednesday Addams.)Story Cons:Gameplay, honestly just this but it's enough to have me not recommending it. The combat gets repetative since there only a few enemy times per level and only 4 weapons. The collectables feel pointless, in the beginning I'd hunt them down, by the middle I would get them if I could and at the end I was ignoring them completely. Even the memories are usually only a character from Alices life saying a single sentence or maybe two when you pick them up. The game seems like jumping puzzles and some hack n' slash wedged into a story. It felt more like the gameplay was a chore you had to do to get to the next bit of story, because the gameplay itself doesn't seem to tell much of the story.Also the multijump function in the game screwed me over even when I did know what to do for the puzzle. You can jump in mid-air to gain height but if you don't do it at the perfect time she just spins in the air staying the same height, multiple times I watched her twirl right next to a ledge she was only maybe 2" under and then fall to her death. The side scroller bits in chapter 3 were really bad for this, trying to jump on a tiger statue head that's shooting fireballs at you only to barely fail the jump and get shot in the face.I enjoyed the feel of the game, the creepy atmosphere was really well done, if the gameplay elements don't sound that bad and it's on sale I wouldn't be against someone picking it up. But for full price I don't think it's worth it, for me the gameplay just didn't live up to the rest of the games elements.

content:
, 2016
												An absolute must-play for everyone who likes dark fantasy, horror and a healthy dose of surrealism. I don't know, for me personally, this may have become the ultimate 'Alice' rendition out of all the media that this classic tale has spawned over the years, both style and story-wise. If I think of Alice and what makes Wonderland special, haunting, beautiful, creepy and alienating, I think of images from this game. The story in the campaign offers many familiar elements and also puts a little bit of it's own twist on the classic, but it does so in a sublime way. It is haunting and because of the video game medium, it immerses you in the surreal nightmare of Alice like no other 'Alice' franchise will. The world looks absolutely stunning. The game keeps throwing new cool looking enemies and beautiful environments at you like there's no end. The gameplay is absolutely great too; I really thought this was a really decent action game that can hold it's own amongst the greats. It's addictive and fun to play. Cool enemies and cool weapons. Sometimes challenging, but nowhere really frustrating.  The story is longer than I expected... at a certain point I was positively surprised that it wasn't over yet. They really didn't deliver half work here! A really decent campaign and an awesome game overall. This is pretty much the beautiful and immersive experience that any Alice fan would hope to find.

												Horror, combat, platforming and puzzles all in one.  Now all we need is the movie!Overall very fun game.  I was pleasently supprised.  Some of the levels did get a little long.  Combat is fun and interesting as the game is always throwing different types of enemies at you each requiring a different strategy.  Almost all enemies are easy 1 on 1 once you learn thier weakness but you will find yourself battling numerous easy ones in the middle of a boss enemy or two, or three...and then nothing is easy anymore.  It makes combat a lot of fun.  You have four weapons all of which can be upgraded.  You can also shadow dodge, jump, or deflect projectiles.  Tons of Gore.  Phys X is neat in game.  The game is not scary type horror but more of the sic and twisted kind of horror.  There are puzzles and mini games that are combined into the level progression.  Not any game breaking bugs but I did have studdering whenever the game was loading stuff in the background.  Was slighty annoying when it happend in the middle of combat.Check the Guides on how to unlock the 30fps cap among other things.  Seriously though someone needs to make a movie...

												I don't know how to adequately describe this game. It is roughly equal parts mystery, hack and slash, shooter, and platformer with limited puzzles. The story plays out such that a normal player is likely to be learning along with Alice as opposed to simply knowing all that is and will happen and could be classified as a psycological thriller or perhaps horror for a genre. I might also tag this as a visual novel as the story progresses rather fluidly as you play instead of getting huge chunks then nothing at all for extended times.They executed the game better than I could have ever expected and while this may not be a game for everyone, just rating it on factors of quality in leiu of personal preferences, I would say this is a perfect game.Voice acting and characters all feel right.Environments are right for each chapter.The music is placed well to set the mood.Controls are smooth (I used a controller).The only things that bothered me were lack of defined boundaries and that it is usually impossible to backtrack if you missed anything. Fortunately death by falling off edges does not carry any significant penalty, so in the end, it really came down to just not being able to back track.

content:

												I had hope for this title. I originally picked this up on sale after seeing a friend play through a level or two and thinking it looked like a relatively fun platformer, and it helped that I am also a fan of the multiple variants on Alice in Wonderland and Through The Looking Glass. But after playing through the entirety of the story mode and reaching the game's conclusion, I was more than happy to be done with it for good.The plot wasn't too complex, though I did wonder if there was anything in the first game that I had missed out on. The story flowed rather well through each of the levels and interludes between them, following Alice as she walks the line between the real world and Wonderland, trying to find out why her visions of Wonderland persist even after she's supposedly "cured" by her psychiatrist. The art style of the levels themselves is fantastic, bringing life to the eccentric and often gruesome aspects of both Wonderland and 1875 Victorian London. Even the combat and platforming elements had a little flair to them, with varying puzzles, multiple different weapons and tools, a triple jump and glide ability, and enemies that follow certain patterns during a fight, but can be defeated in a number of ways.However, I felt the problem with the game was a lack of diversity in platforming elements and puzzles. Platforming didn't get that much more difficult from the start of the game to the finish. Some portions of levels seem like reskins of sections contained in older levels, and though a few of the puzzles were unique, at least half of them were revisited throughout the course of the game. Though the first few hours playing the game were fresh and entertaining, it quickly devolved into seeing how quickly I could finish the rehashed bits of the levels to attempt to move on to something new. There was a level of progression that just wasn't there. It got rather boring fairly quickly, and the repetitiveness of the game is most definitely the main cause of that for me. (The addition of requiring activation through EA as well as Steam was also quite frustrating, as sometimes the game was rendered unlaunchable for periods of time.)Unless you're a diehard fan of either Alice in Wonderland, American McGee, or both, I would not recommend picking up this game.

And after a while you just get tired of it. On a positive note, the graphics are much better and McGee's imagination is still quite active. It's got most of the charm of the original Alice but you wouldn't like this one if you did't play the original. For example (spoiler), you get to see the mechanical version of the Mad Hatter, but you're never told why he's like that. They just assumed you knew that from the first game. It doesn't help that it feels like it's just a retelling of the first game (note: I haven't finished the game yet). The first few stages let you get a feel of what the original Wonderland felt like, just like the first game. But they take you into the new Wonderland way too early and they show you what the new version looks like without you getting attached to the original. Unfortunately, the game doesn't have enough charm to keep you playing for long. If you didn't pay the first before this, I suggest you start there. You'll enjoy this version more if you do that. If you did play the first, you could pick this game up on sale, but paying full price for it just doesn't feel right for me.

content:
r 5, 2014
												My interest in this game was piqued, paradoxically, by the IGN review. You know, the one that gave it a 6.5 which, by IGN standards, meant it wasn't worth playing to them? They're main complaint was that there was an overabundance of invisible walls, and I found that sufficiently idiotic to be interested. I have no past experience with American McGee's games so I was looking at Madness Returns with fresh eyes. All the screenshots I saw as I looked into it made it look more and more intrigueing, but at the time I wasn't really interested in this genre. Fastforward to the 2013 Christmas sale, and I finally got around to buying it. Boy did it ever live up to expectations. I have simply not played a game with as diverse an atmosphere, as creative a world, and as well-realized a story.Let's start with the atmosphere. I think many would be tempted to say that "dark" is the atmosphere here. While that is a prevailing theme, the method of presentation of that theme varies significantly between each of the worlds. From the slight perversion of the Vale of Tears signaling things to come to the oppressiveness of Hatters domain to the heavy, heavy irony of the Deluded Depths, this game uses every trick in the book to convey the same message.What message? Well, that's simple: "Something is seriously wrong."Every world feels incredibly distinct and dear God is that ever refreshing. None of the worlds really feel borrowed from anywhere else, and because of the distinctness from every world that came before it, starting a new level is a true exploration. Some of the levels are just awe inspriring, both when you first see them and while you're making your way through them.As for the story, it may seem to be somewhat hamfisted at first glance; the somewhat melodramatic voice acting, the comic book cutscenes, and the over the top characters. But once you start hitting the ends of levels, that all changes dramatically.The keys you find to your sanity begin to unlock the subtle turnings of the story. Obviously, without giving any spoilers, let's just say that a story of this magnitude and gravity has very rarely ever had the dubious distinction of being attached to a video game.Most writers in this industry would have beaten us over the head with the plot twists, having the characters wallow in their self pity, all  while stripping everything resembling a truely grotesque detail. As an example of everything this game DOESN'T do, I need only point to Bioshock Infinite's handling of racism with kid gloves. Every punch that game pulled, this one delivered with follow through and, while the subjects being covered were dramatically different, they were also so much more pertinent, so much more dangerous, and ultimately leagues more risky.Through level design, art, characters, and dialog, this game accomplishes a hundred times more towards elliciting an emotional response than any other game I've played outside of an RPG.Of course, no diamond in the rough is complete without some rough edges. Though I absolutely loved most of this game, as the game reaches the end, several nuisances within the combat system become major irritations, then progress well past that into infuriations. Auto-targetting is almost useless except against very specific, and powerful, enemy types and, in a very misguided effort to increase difficulty late stage, the developers intentionally exploit this irritation to make combatting those powerful enemy types artificially harder. This culminates in an end-boss whose PITA Level I have never seen equalled by a game of this quality.Though that issue and the overall repetitive nature of the enemy types towards the last third of the game can easily be explained by EA's ceasing of funding, that really doesn't change the fact that combat is at best more boring and at worst actively angering in this later stage.But it is still absolutely worth it to play through to the end. When those answers are finally given, even if you'd figured many of them out already, the result is a terrifying resolution to a plot that NO other major publisher would touch with a 39 and 1/2 foot pole.This is something only Spicy Horse is giving you right now, and for all its faults in the late-stage gameplay department, I have no reservations about recommending this game to anyone not completely brainwashed by the media's hype-machine.

												I wanted to really like this game, I did. I came into it after hearing some of the negative reviews and thought, "Well all the negatives they stated probably won't bother me" because they were all about dated graphics and whatnot and I really don't care about that. I thought the game was actually quite beautiful at times and I enjoyed the graphics and art style for the most part. The biggest issue I had with this game is it just overstayed its welcome. While the story was interesting (I enjoyed the slower story moments the most) there was just way too much that didn't progress the story at all and just had you doing the same basic tasks over and over. You'd do some platforming, fight some bad guys, find some secrets, then repeat. There are a few different enemies, and new enemy types come in over the course of the game, but once you figure out each enemy pattern the majority are relatively easy to fight, if you can get the lock on to work that is. The lock on system works for simple enemies, but when faced with a boss it tends to hurt you rather than help you. The lock-on camera is locked in a position so if you move around an enemy you'll find yourself having to turn it off just to let the camera fix itself, or else you'll dodge straight into an enemy attack. Other than the lock-on feature, the combat is generally pretty fun for awhile, it just gets old once you fight the same enemy type over an over for a few hours. The game is also pretty linear, other than a few secret areas (which are for the most part are all reached the same two ways). You'll find yourself going exactly where the developers want you to, with invisible walls blocking anything that may look like a chance of exploration. The invisible walls contribute to my last major gripe, the game feels clunky and outdated. This includes the animation, controls, and mostly platforming. Alice can't climb edges, so if you make a jump and just one toe is below the platform, ledge, etc. you wanted to get on, you plummet straight to your death.All in all, I wanted to recommend this game, at first I was very content but after awhile the feeling died down and I found myself playing it just to beat it. The game does have a good story, and the art style is pretty cool, but everything else is just overly monotonous and extremely disappointing.

I'd rather deal with batmans lackluster combat than this game. Platforming: Already told ya above ^ Puzzles: The puzzles kinda correlate with the platforming sadly enough. There are a few ACTUAL puzzles you have to put together throughout the game and they aren't that challenging... Just don't overthink it and you'd be fine. Story: My version... Short and Sweet. A girl named Alice that has a ♥♥♥♥ed up mind from losing her parents in a fire when she was young, now she's trying to figure out how the fire started...Pretty lackluster story right? Yeah, I thought so too. Final Verdict.... Don't buy this game unless you have an obsession for jumping and gliding, if not. I recommend something like rayman... That's actually decent.

												Alice: Madness Returns is very much a retro-styled title in terms of gameplay, which will turn many people off right away.  The floaty and imprecise platforming is sure to discourage the uninitiated.  The easiest way to review it is to put it in terms of it's previous title.  Did you play American McGee's Alice?  No?  Wait for a steam sale so you're not too disappointed if you hate it.You did play AMA?  Did you like it?  No?  Skip this title completely.  Chances are very good that you were turned off by either AMA's floaty platforming or American McGee's childhood destroying storyline.  Both are still in full effect here.  Even though the jumping physics have been tightened up a bit, it is still frustrating at times.You did like AMA?  You love it, and you're one of those rabid fans that did a happy dance when you found out that your favorite (only?) gothic absurdist horror title was finally getting a remake?  (Yeah, I'm one of those.)  WHAT ARE YOU WAITING FOR?  BUY MADNESS RETURNS!  NOW!  YOU'RE GOING TO LOVE IT!Hope this helps.

												Sadly I do not recomend this game. It is a nice idea etc etc but unfortunately there are some technichal issues which took away from the game so much that I had to  force myself to play - not something I really look for in a game.For example, I found myself having to redo many of the platforming elements again and again simply because it was difficult to understand when certain controls would be usable. In other words, when you jump the double jump was slow to respond and the 'dash' would not always work. Additionally, the camera control left something to be desired as I was often left with the impression that I really couldn't predict where I would land. In a platformer this is frustrating and I wasn't left with the impression that my failures were related to my level of skill as a player.The other issue was that the scenary was annoyingly glitchy. It gave the impression that they used big cube-shaped coliders which didn't always fit what the game object looked like. In other words, there would frequently be massive twice-Alice-sized spaces between objects yet the way was still blocked even if you became 'small Alice'.Shame really.

r 25, 2014
												The game looks absolutely beautiful. Everything from the artwork, level design and animations just look phenominal. Each area really has its own beauty and unique atmosphere.The story is interesting, with lots of colorful characters and more than a few twists. Alice takes quite a few very dark turns as she explores her imagination to escape her real life problems.The gameplay is good although a little on the easy side, with a spammable invincibility move later on. There are a fair share of weapons, some feel better than others, but they all follow the Alice theme pretty well. The platforming and puzzles are pretty standard, nothing super innovative here but still good.Overall the game is good, with only a few hangups. For example, the non combat areas can be a bit restrictive and linear. Would say its a solid fit for anyone looking for an action platformer with a little madness.
